_prev_prog_3.Description:
Amines Plant No. 1 - U.S. Amines:

U.S. Amines owns and operates two multi-purpose amine plants on site.  The plants are called:

1.  Amines Plant No. 1
2.  Amines Plant No. 2

RMP specific to Cyclohexylamine:

These units include one common RMP listed chemical above the RMP threshold, cyclohexylamine.  Cyclohexylamine can be produced by both plants, and can be stored in the following locations:

1.  Amines Plant No.1 has daily production storage tanks in the unit.
2.  Amines Plant No.2 has daily production storage tanks in the unit.
3.  There are two storage tanks in our tank farm storage facility.  Both plants can use these tanks.
4.  The site can also store cyclohexylamine in railcars, while they are awaiting shipment.

Operations of these storage locations and production of cyclohexylamine fall under the site PSM program.  The storage locations are covered by automatic and/or manual fire suppression systems.  The storage areas are curbed or diked with hold-up volume adequate to contain all of the tank contents.

RMP specific to Amines Plant No. 1:

Amines Plant No. 1 also includes the following RMP listed chemicals above the RMP threshold:

1.  Ammonia
2.  Ethylamine
3.  Isopropylamine

Ammonia

Operations of the storage locations for ammonia and the operations using ammonia fall under the site PSM program.  Ammonia is stored as a liquefied gas.  There are three storage tanks for pure ammonia which do not have storage containment dikes because diking would not contain the ammonia from evaporation.  Storage for ammonia within the process unit does include diking as the ammonia stored in the process is not pure and diking would contain some of the material that would not immediately evaporate.  

Ethylamine and Isopropylamine

Operations of the storage locations and production of ethylamine and isopropylamine fall under the site PSM program.  The storage locations are covered by automatic and/or manual fire suppression systems.  The storage areas are curbed or diked with hold-up volume adequate to contain all of the tank contents.

RMP elements common to the site:

The plants are subject to and operated in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations.  The site maintains one PSM plan which includes application of the OSHA PSM rule.

The site has policies that go beyond the OSHA PSM rule.  Some of those polices are listed below:
1.  Sight glass use: Sight glass use is discouraged in hazardous chemical service.  In cases where sight level indicators are needed, magnetically coupled, metal gauges are used or other provisions are made to protect against releases from breakage.
2.  Quarter-turn valves (1" size or less) are fitted with oval handles to reduce the risk of releases from bumping a straight handle valve open.
3.  Qualitative risk assessment is incorporated into our PHA and MOC process in order to provide more consistent evaluation of risk.  This provides better guidance in reducing risk, over the HAZOP only type of analysis.
4.  The plant belongs to and participates in a local emergency response group (LEPC) and a local community advisory panel (LCAP).
5.  All operators are trained and certified in the jobs they perform.
6.  All employees have the authority to shut down any process or stop any job, in order to maintain safe operation.
7.  A self-paced training program covers job specific tasks, principles of chemical engineering, safety, and regulatory issues.
8.  All plant operators are trained in emergency response.
9.  The plant has an extensive fire fighting system with monitor nozzles, hoses, foam generating capability and water reservoir.
10.  The plant has a portable emergency command vehicle complete with air monitoring equipment, radio and cellular phone systems, emergency response and decontamination materials.
11.  The plant alarm system is tested weekly.
12.  Emergency response personnel are trained in first aid and CPR.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
At US Amines, we are dedicated to being an industry leader in protecting the environment, the health, and safety of both our employees and the communities in which we operate.  Like our community neighbors, the people who work at the Bucks site want a clean, safe environment, with no illnesses or injuries at work, home, or play.  That is why US Amines has a "zero incident" goal.  We are committed to reducing emissions and continuously improving our performance toward zero injuries and zero environmental incidents.

The amines plant began operations in 1974.  We manufacture amines in five product groups.  We also operate an on-site fertilizer plant owned by IB Nitrogen that is not covered by RMP.  We have about 45 site employees and 15 resident contractors.

The US Amines product groups are:
     Isopropylamines
     Propylamines
     Cyclohexylamines
     Ethylamines
     Butylamines
These products are used by other chemical companies to make herbicides, insecticides, and pharmaceuticals.

The IB Nitrogen product is:
     Isobutylidene diurea
This product is a slow-release specialty fertilizer used on golf courses and turf farms.  It is also used in plant nurseries for growing ornamentals such as azaleas and poinsettias.

The US Amines Bucks Plant participates in a local community advisory panel and works with other area industrial facilities to promote safety in our operations.  The LeMoyne Community Advisory Panel and the LeMoyne Industrial Park companies are recognized by local, state, and national organizations for outstanding cooperation.  This continued partnership ensures that the community where we all live and work will be a safe place now and in the future.

Plant Organization:

The plant has a site director (plant manager) who oversees all plant activities.  The staff includes an occupational safety manager, process safety manager, environmental manager, production engineer for US Amines operations, production manager for IB Nitrogen operations, and maint

enance engineers.

All plant employees must attend at least one safety meeting per month.  Safety meetings include training on regulatory requirements and plant specific issues.  Testing is conducted in safety meetings to insure the information is understood.

Plant operators are members of the BEST team (the Bucks Emergency Services Team).  They are trained in the specifics of incident command, emergency response, and medical response.  The plant conducts weekly tests of the plant alarm system and conducts emergency response drills.

The US Amines Bucks plant complies with RMP and OSHA 1910.119, (the OSHA Process Safety Regulation) through our Process Safety Management Program.  The Bucks plant manages all plant processes per our Process Safety Management program.  The program meets all of the RMP and OSHA requirements such as:
*  Develop and implement a risk management system.
*  Conduct hazard assessments of all processes.
*  Implement accident prevention requirements.
*  Develop an emergency response program that is coordinated with
    local agencies.
*  Track and analyze incidents to prevent reoccurrence.

The RMP regulation has an additional requirement to develop worst case and alternate case scenarios and make them available to the public.  A summary of these studies is presented below:

Worst Case Scenarios:
The Worst Case Scenarios are meant to represent the worst possible incident. There has never been a Worst Case Scenario type event in the 30-year history of the Bucks plant.  The EPA has provided a procedure for calculating the quantity of chemical that could be released and the distance it could travel for a Worst Case Scenario:
  1. Assume that your largest tank of listed chemical breaks open and spills all of its contents in 10 minutes.
  2. Determine the maximum distance where there is concern for the public being exposed, based on the EPA supplied exposure data.
  3. Only one worst case scenario must be reported to the EPA, but for the sake of com

pleteness the worst case scenario for each covered chemical is presented below.

Listed Chemical      Maximum Distance
Ammonia                  3.6 miles
Propionitrile            9.9 miles
Cyclohexylamine          0.9 miles
Ethylamine               0.5 miles
Isopropylamine           1.1 miles

Alternate Release Scenario:
The Worst Case Scenarios are meant to represent the worst possible incident. Additionally, RMP requires each site to determine a less severe scenario that could potentially impact the public.  These are called the Alternate Release Scenarios.  The EPA provides guidance on how to determine the size of an Alternate Release Scenario.  The scenarios below are based on a release of 1000 pounds per minute lasting for 30 minutes with no operator response.

Listed Chemical       Maximum distance
Ammonia                   0.2 miles
Propionitrile             1.2 miles
Cyclohexylamine           0.2 miles
Ethylamine                0.1 miles
Isopropylamine            0.1 miles

Plant 5 Year Accident History: 
RMP requires us to tell the public about accidents involving the listed chemicals that resulted in injuries or serious on-site or off-site impact.

Accident  1998   1999   2000   2001   2002   2003YTD 
RMP          1         0         0         0         0        0

In 1998, a worker inhaled a small amount of ammonia vapor.  The release occurred when the worker opened a valve on a section of piping that had not been cleaned.  He was sent to our first aid clinic where he was examined and then returned to work.  There was no serious injury; first aid was given as a precautionary measure.  

How We Keep Our Plant Safe:

People: Our Most Valuable Safety Resource
1. All plant operators are trained and certified in the jobs they do.
2. All employees have the authority to shut down any process or stop any job, in order to maintain safe operation.
3. A self-paced training program covers job specific tasks, principles of chemical processing, safety, and regulatory i

ssues.
 
Equipment: Maintained in Safe Condition
1. All plant process equipment is subjected to mechanical integrity inspections to look for corrosion or wear.
2. Safety devices such as pressure relief valves and shutdown systems are inspected and tested on a regular basis.
3. A thermographic camera allows us to check for temperature deviations in equipment, check for electrical faults, and verify levels.
4. Glass level gauges have been replaced with metal, magnetically-coupled gauges.

Safety Systems: Protective Safety Net
1. All storage tanks and process vessels are protected against over-pressure by safety relief valves, much like the safety relief valve on your home water heater.
2. Process safety systems are programmed in our process control computers.  If a designated level, pressure, temperature, or other parameter goes out of range, the process will shut down automatically.
3. Oxygen analyzers protect the integrity of key equipment including various boiler, compressor, and reactor operations.
4. All plant modifications and procedure changes undergo a management of change process that involves operations, maintenance, engineering, and management review.

Prepared: For Emergency Response
1. All plant operators are trained in emergency response, fire fighting, and must pass a physical agility test.
2. The plant has an extensive fire fighting system with monitor nozzles, hoses, foam generating capability, and water reservoir. 
3. The plant has a portable emergency command vehicle complete with air monitoring equipment, radio and cellular phone systems, emergency response, and decontamination materials.
4. The plant alarm system is tested weekly to ensure that employees know how to use it.
5. Emergency response personnel are trained in first aid and CPR.
